choices.text: Primary CBD stone; more common in developing countries
Primary CBD stone; most common type is cholesterol stone
Secondary CBD stone; most common type is brown stone
Secondary CBD stone; formed in the gall bladder and more common in developed countries

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and fever. Imaging reveals a stone in the common bile duct. Upon further evaluation, it is determined that the stone most likely originated from the gall bladder. Which of the following statements is true regarding the type of stone present?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A (Primary CBD stone; more common in developing countries): Incorrect. Primary CBD stones are formed inside the common bile duct, and while they may be more common in developing countries due to worm infestations, they are typically brown stones. This answer does not fit with the formation in the gallbladder.

Option B (Primary CBD stone; most common type is cholesterol stone): Incorrect. Primary CBD stones are usually brown stones, not cholesterol stones. Cholesterol stones are more commonly associated with gallbladder formation.

Option C (Secondary CBD stone; most common type is brown stone): Incorrect. Secondary CBD stones are formed in the gallbladder and pass into the common bile duct. Cholesterol stones are the most common in secondary CBD stones.

Option D (Secondary CBD stone; formed in the gall bladder and more common in developed countries): Correct. Secondary CBD stones are formed in the gallbladder, often cholesterol stones, and are more common in developed countries. These stones pass into the common bile duct, leading to complications like jaundice and biliary colic.

Tags:

Topic: Biliary Tract Diseases, Gallbladder Stones

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 71, page no. 1243

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with gallbladder cancer with involvement of the peri-muscular connective tissue on the hepatic side. Based on the staging system, what is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A (Laparoscopic cholecystectomy): Incorrect. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is suitable for early-stage gallbladder cancer (T1a), but this patient has T2B disease, requiring more extensive surgery.

Option B (Extended cholecystectomy): Correct. For patients with T2B (invasion of peri-muscular connective tissue towards hepatic side), an extended cholecystectomy is recommended, which includes the removal of the gallbladder and regional lymph nodes along the cystic duct, CBD, peri-choledochal, and retro-pancreatic areas.

Option C (Extended cholecystectomy + Extended Right hepatectomy): Incorrect. This treatment is reserved for more advanced cases, such as T3 (serosal perforation or direct hepatic invasion) or T4 (involvement of portal vein or hepatic artery).

Option D (Palliation): Incorrect. Palliation with chemotherapy (gemcitabine and cisplatin) is indicated for metastatic or advanced disease (stage IV), not for T2B disease.

Staging of Carcinoma Gall Bladder - 8th AJCC (2017) TNM Classification

Treatment Based on Staging

Extended cholecystectomy: Encompasses removal of the gallbladder, segments IVb and V of the liver, and regional lymph nodes.

Tags:

Topic: Gallbladder Cancer, Staging and Treatment

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-71, page number-1258

choices.text: Vaccinate immediately after splenectomy, including pneumococcal, Hib, and Men ACWY
Vaccinate at least 2 weeks before elective splenectomy, with pneumococcal, Hib, Men ACWY, and influenza vaccines
Vaccinate 8 weeks after splenectomy, with pneumococcal and Men ACWY only
Vaccinate 8-12 weeks before elective splenectomy, with pneumococcal, Hib, and Men ACWY vaccines only

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for elective splenectomy. When should the vaccinations be administered, and which vaccines are recommended for post-splenectomy care?
questions.solution:
Option A (Vaccinate immediately after splenectomy): Incorrect. Vaccination should occur before splenectomy, ideally 8-12 weeks prior to the procedure, or at least 2 weeks before. Immediate vaccination after splenectomy is not recommended.

Option B (Vaccinate at least 2 weeks before elective splenectomy): Correct. Vaccination should ideally be done 8-12 weeks prior to elective splenectomy. The recommended vaccines include pneumococcal (PCV13 and PPSV23), Hib, MenACWY, and influenza.

Option C (Vaccinate 8 weeks after splenectomy): Incorrect. Vaccines should be administered before splenectomy whenever possible, or at least two weeks post-splenectomy if not given earlier.

Option D (Vaccinate 8-12 weeks before elective splenectomy, with pneumococcal, Hib, and MenACWY vaccines only): Incorrect. While the timing is correct, influenza vaccination should also be included in the vaccination protocol for post-splenectomy care.

Post-Splenectomy Care - Vaccination

  • Patients should be vaccinated at least 2 weeks prior, and ideally 8 to 12 weeks prior to elective splenectomy.
  • When vaccines cannot be given prior to emergency splenectomy, vaccines should be given at least two weeks after splenectomy.

Pneumococcal vaccine:

  • A dose of PCV13 followed by PPSV23 ≥8 weeks later is advised.
  • Revaccinate every five to seven years thereafter.

H. influenzae type b vaccine:

  • A single dose of Hib vaccine is recommended.
  • Revaccination is needed every ten years.

Meningococcal vaccination:

  • Two doses of the MenACWY vaccine are given ≥8 weeks apart.
  • Revaccination is needed every five years.

Influenza vaccination:

  • Vaccination against seasonal influenza should be given annually.

Tags:

Topic: Splenectomy, Vaccination Protocols

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-70 ,page number. -1231

questions.text: Which of the following terms corresponds to a collection that has a well-defined wall and has been present for more than 4 weeks?
questions.solution:
Option A (Acute peripancreatic collection): Incorrect. This refers to a collection that is < 4 weeks old, and it does not have a fully definable wall.

Option B (Acute necrotic collection): Incorrect. This is a < 4 weeks old collection that is not well-defined and represents a collection of pancreatic necrosis.

Option C (Pseudocyst): Correct. A pseudocyst is a collection > 4 weeks old with a well-defined wall. It is typically fluid-filled and occurs due to pancreatic inflammation or trauma.

Option D (Walled-off necrosis): Incorrect. Walled-off necrosis refers to a collection of pancreatic necrosis > 4 weeks old, but it often involves a more complex wall with necrotic tissue.

Key Points:

  • Pseudocyst: Typically occurs > 4 weeks after acute pancreatitis and has a well-defined wall.
  • Walled-off necrosis: Similar in timing but involves a more complex structure containing necrotic tissue.

Tags:

Topic: Pancreatic Collections

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 72 , page number. 1274.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can cause a raised serum amylase level, other than acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A: Incorrect. Gallstone is a cause of acute pancreatitis and would be associated with a raised serum amylase level due to pancreatitis, not direct causes.

Option B: Correct. Upper gastrointestinal tract perforation (e.g., perforated peptic ulcer) can lead to a raised serum amylase level, as amylase may leak into the bloodstream from the gastrointestinal tract.

Option C: Incorrect. Chronic liver disease typically does not lead to a significant increase in serum amylase levels. It may cause other biochemical changes, but amylase elevation is not characteristic.

Option D: Incorrect. Acute myocardial infarction does not typically cause a rise in serum amylase levels, as amylase is not directly related to myocardial injury. It is typically associated with pancreatic or salivary gland issues.

Causes of Raised Serum Amylase Level Other Than Acute Pancreatitis

  • Upper gastrointestinal tract perforation
  • Mesenteric infarction
  • Torsion of an intra-abdominal viscus
  • Retroperitoneal haematoma
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Macroamylasaemia
  • Renal failure
  • Salivary gland inflammation

Tags:

Topic: Causes of Raised Amylase Levels

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-72, page no. 1262.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the criteria for severe acute pancreatitis based on the Atlanta Classification (2013)?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A: Incorrect. This describes mild acute pancreatitis, which involves no organ failure and no complications, not severe acute pancreatitis.

Option B: Incorrect. This describes moderately severe acute pancreatitis, where organ failure resolves within 48 hours or complications are present without persistent organ failure.

Option C: Correct. Severe acute pancreatitis is defined by persistent organ failure for more than 48 hours, which may involve single or multiple organs.

Option D: Incorrect. This describes transient organ failure and complications, which are seen in moderately severe acute pancreatitis, not severe pancreatitis.

Atlanta Classification of Acute Pancreatitis (2013)

  • Mild acute pancreatitis:
    • No organ failure;
    • No local or systemic complications.
  • Moderately severe acute pancreatitis:
    • Organ failure that resolves within 48 hours (transient organ failure); and/or
    • Local or systemic complications without persistent organ failure.
  • Severe acute pancreatitis:
    • Persistent organ failure (>48 hours);
    • Single organ failure;
    • Multiple organ failure.

Tags:

Topic: Acute Pancreatitis, Atlanta Classification

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter -72, page no. 1271.

choices.text: Intractable peptic ulcer disease, diarrhoea, and recurrent haemorrhage
Migratory necrolytic skin rash, glossitis, stomatitis, and diabetes
Profuse watery diarrhoea, hypotension, and abdominal pain

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely clinical presentation of a glucagonoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A: Incorrect. This description fits a gastrinoma, which is characterized by intractable or recurrent peptic ulcer disease with complications like haemorrhage, perforation, and diarrhoea.

Option B: Correct. Glucagonoma presents with a characteristic migratory necrolytic skin rash, glossitis, stomatitis, angular cheilitis, along with severe weight loss, diarrhoea, and diabetes.

Option C: Incorrect. This description is typical of a VIPoma, which causes profuse watery diarrhoea, hypotension, and abdominal pain due to vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) secretion.

Option D: Incorrect. This presentation is typical of a carcinoid tumour, which causes flushing, sweating, diarrhoea, and oedema due to serotonin and other bioactive substances secreted by the tumour.

Glucagonoma or Hyperglycemic Cutaneous Syndrome

Also known as "4" D Syndrome:

  • Diabetes Mellitus
  • Dermatitis - Necrolytic Erythema Migrans (Most common symptom)
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Depression

The most common site of tumors is the body and tail of the pancreas.

Key Points:

  • Glucagonoma primarily causes skin rash, mucosal lesions, weight loss, and metabolic disturbances such as diabetes.

Tags:

Topic: Endocrine Tumours, Pancreatic Tumours, Glucagonoma

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-57, page no. 905.

choices.text: Type I biliary-type pain with liver enzymes >2 times normal, dilated CBD >12 mm, and prolonged biliary drainage time
Type II pancreatic-type pain with amylase/lipase >2 times upper normal limit, dilated pancreatic duct, and prolonged pancreatic drainage time
Type III biliary-type pain only, with no other criteria needed for diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the correct criteria for diagnosis of Biliary-type and Pancreatic-type Sphincter of Oddi Dysfunction (SOD)?
questions.solution:
Option A: Correct. Type I Biliary-type SOD includes biliary-type pain, liver enzymes >2 times normal on at least two occasions during pain episodes, dilated CBD >12 mm, and prolonged biliary drainage time (>45 minutes).

Option B: Correct. Type II Pancreatic-type SOD involves pancreatic-type pain, elevated amylase and/or lipase >2 times upper normal limit on at least two occasions during pain episodes, dilated pancreatic duct (head >6 mm, body >5 mm), and prolonged pancreatic drainage time (>9 minutes).

Option C: Correct. Type III SOD, whether biliary or pancreatic, is characterized by the presence of pain only, without additional criteria such as enzyme or ductal abnormalities.

Option D: Correct. All of the options accurately describe the various types of Biliary-type and Pancreatic-type Sphincter of Oddi Dysfunction based on the clinical and diagnostic criteria.

Key Points:

  • Biliary-type SOD and Pancreatic-type SOD are differentiated based on the type of pain (biliary or pancreatic), along with specific criteria such as enzyme levels, duct dilation, and drainage times.

Tags:

Topic: Sphincter of Oddi Dysfunction, Diagnostic Criteria

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter -72 , page number. -1280.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria are used to determine the need for liver transplantation in cases of paracetamol toxicity?
questions.solution:
Option A: Correct. Paracetamol toxicity can be a criterion for liver transplantation if the arterial pH is <7.30 or if INR is >6.5, indicating severe liver dysfunction.

Option B: Correct. The presence of serum creatinine >3.4 mg/dL and Grade III or IV encephalopathy are also important factors for assessing the severity of paracetamol toxicity and the need for transplantation.

Option C: Correct. Hyperlactatemia and hyperphosphatemia are significant predictors of poor prognosis in paracetamol toxicity and suggest a higher risk for requiring a liver transplant.

Option D: Correct. All the above criteria together are used to assess the severity of paracetamol toxicity and determine whether liver transplantation is needed for the patient.

King's College Selection Criteria for Liver Transplantation in Acute Liver Failure

Paracetamol toxicity

Criteria met if arterial pH <7.30 OR/AND All three of the following present:

  • INR >6.5 (PT >100 s)
  • Serum creatinine 3.4 mg/dL (301 µmol/L)
  • Grade III or IV encephalopathy

Additionally, hyperlactatemia or hyperphosphatemia are strong predictors of poor prognosis for survival without transplantation.

Non-paracetamol toxicity

Criteria met if INR >6.5 (PT >100 s) OR/AND Three out of five of the following present:

  • Age less than 10 or greater than 40
  • Aetiology non-A, non-B hepatitis, idiosyncratic drug reactions
  • Duration of jaundice before development of encephalopathy >7 days
  • PT greater than 50 s (approximate INR >3.5)
  • Serum bilirubin >18 mg/dL (300 µmol/L)

Tags:

Topic: Paracetamol Toxicity, Liver Transplantation

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 69, page no. 1195.

choices.text: Amoebic liver abscess is more common in immunocompromised individuals than pyogenic liver abscess.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key distinguishing feature between an amoebic liver abscess and a pyogenic liver abscess?
questions.solution:
Options Explanation:

Option A: Incorrect. Both amoebic and pyogenic liver abscesses are more common in males, with pyogenic liver abscesses being more frequently seen in immunocompromised individuals.

Option B: Incorrect. Pyogenic liver abscesses are more likely to present with more severe jaundice compared to amoebic liver abscesses.

Option C: Correct. Amoebic liver abscess typically has "anchovy sauce" pus, which lacks neutrophils, while pyogenic liver abscess pus is rich in neutrophils, reflecting the bacterial infection.

Option D: Incorrect. Entamoeba Histolytica causes amoebic liver abscess, whereas pyogenic liver abscess is often caused by bacteria, with Escherichia coli being the most common pathogen.

questions.text: Based on the Barcelona Clinic Liver Group staging system for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), which of the following treatment strategies is most appropriate for a patient diagnosed with Stage 0 (Very Early Stage) HCC with a single tumor less than 2 cm, normal portal pressure, and no associated diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A (Liver transplantation): Incorrect. Liver transplantation is generally indicated in cases where the patient has a single tumor greater than 2 cm, or when there are multiple tumors or associated cirrhosis. However, for Stage 0 HCC with a single tumor less than 2 cm and no associated diseases, resection is preferred over liver transplantation.

Option B (Transcatheter arterial chemoembolization [TACE]): Incorrect. TACE is primarily indicated for patients with intermediate-stage HCC (Stage B) or advanced stage with portal invasion. It is not typically used for very early-stage disease where curative treatment options like resection are available.

Option C (Resection): Correct. In Stage 0 (Very Early Stage) HCC with a single tumor less than 2 cm and no associated diseases, resection is the curative treatment of choice. This treatment has a high success rate and can achieve long-term survival with a median OS (overall survival) greater than 60 months.

Option D (Sorafenib): Incorrect. Sorafenib is used for patients with advanced-stage HCC (Stage C) with portal invasion or distant metastasis, where curative resection is not possible. It is not indicated for early-stage HCC.

Tags:

Topic: Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC), Barcelona Clinic Liver Group Staging

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 69, page no. 1215.

questions.text: Which of the following tyrosine kinase inhibitors is primarily used in the treatment of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) resistant to Imatinib?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A (Sunitinib): Correct. Sunitinib is a promiscuous tyrosine kinase inhibitor (inhibits PDGFR, VEGFR, KIT, FLT) and is used in GISTs resistant to Imatinib, as well as in renal cell carcinoma.

Option B (Gefitinib): Incorrect. Gefitinib is an EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor used for non-small cell lung cancer.

Option C (Lapatinib): Incorrect. Lapatinib inhibits tyrosine kinase associated with EGFR and HER2, primarily used in breast cancer treatment.

Option D (Erlotinib): Incorrect. Erlotinib is another EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor used for non-small cell lung cancer and pancreatic cancer.

Tags:

Topic: Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors, Oncology

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-12, page no. 213

choices.text: Von Hippel-Lindau Syndrome; Kidney, Brain, Pancreas

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the PTEN gene. What syndrome is most likely associated with these findings, and which cancers is she at increased risk for?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A (Li-Fraumeni Syndrome): Incorrect. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is associated with TP53 mutations and predisposes to cancers like breast cancer, sarcoma, and brain tumors.

Option B (Cowden's Syndrome): Correct. Cowden's syndrome is caused by mutations in the PTEN gene on chromosome 10q23.3 and is associated with an increased risk of breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancers.

Option C (Lynch Syndrome): Incorrect. Lynch syndrome is associated with mismatch repair gene mutations and predisposes to colorectal, endometrial, and gastric cancers.

Option D (von Hippel-Lindau Syndrome): Incorrect. This syndrome involves mutations in the VHL gene and is associated with kidney, brain, and pancreatic tumors.

Key Points:

  • Cowden's Syndrome: Caused by PTEN mutations (chromosome 10q23.3).
  • Cancer Risk: High risk for breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancers.

Tags:

Topic: Hereditary Cancer Syndromes

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-12, page no. 202

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2)?
questions.solution:
Option A (Optic gliomas): Incorrect. Optic gliomas are commonly associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1), not NF2.

Option B (Acoustic neuromas): Correct. Acoustic neuromas (vestibular schwannomas) are hallmark tumors of NF2, often bilateral and affecting cranial nerve VIII.

Option C (Primitive neuroectodermal tumors): Incorrect. These are more commonly seen in NF1, not NF2.

Option D (Astrocytomas): Incorrect. Astrocytomas are associated with NF1 rather than NF2.

Key Points:

  • NF1: Associated with optic gliomas, astrocytomas, and neurofibromas.
  • NF2: Characterized by acoustic neuromas, spinal tumors, and meningiomas.
  • Bilateral acoustic neuromas are diagnostic of NF2.

Tags:

Topic: Neurofibromatosis, Tumor Associations

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter- 12, page number -203.

questions.text: Which of the following lymph nodes is associated with periumbilical metastatic cutaneous nodules, often seen in advanced intra-abdominal malignancies?
questions.solution:
Option A (Sister Mary Joseph Nodes): Correct. These are periumbilical metastatic cutaneous nodules, commonly associated with advanced intra-abdominal malignancies such as gastric or pancreatic cancer.

Option B (Virchow Nodes): Incorrect. Virchow nodes are located in the left supraclavicular region and are associated with metastatic gastrointestinal cancers, particularly gastric cancer.

Option C (Irish Nodes): Incorrect. Irish nodes refer to lymph nodes in the left axilla associated with metastatic stomach cancer.

Option D (Delphian Nodes): Incorrect. Delphian nodes are pre-cricoid/pre-tracheal lymph nodes commonly involved in laryngeal and thyroid malignancies.

Tags:

Topic: Lymph Nodes in Oncology

References: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-67, page no. 1174.
